Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Passive Seismic Protective Systems for Nonstructural Systems and Components in Multistory Building

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program award is to protect through isolation devices and energy dissipation mechanisms critical equipment and components within essential multistory buildings during earthquake events. This objective will be accomplished through theoretical analysis and real-environment, full-scale laboratory tests. Specific research tasks are aimed at (1) examining the ability of passive systems settings to protect critical equipment and components; (2) identifying optimal characteristics of the protective measures; (3) identifying and evaluating the applicability of performance limits of the passive systems under different types of ground motions; (4) validating the equipment-passive systems arrangements using the NEES facility at the University at Buffalo SUNY; and (5) implementing a framework for analysis, design, and implementation of the protective measures. This project aims to fill current gaps in knowledge regarding interrelationship among multiple variables controlling the behavior of equipment and components within multistory buildings during an earthquake. The expected contributions include the validation of high-performance platforms that permit straightforward predictions of performance of equipment and components, and cost-effective implementations of protective measures. The research and education plans include both industry cooperation for systems implementation and a comprehensive education program aimed at promoting participation of underrepresented groups in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM).

Implementing the seismic protective options emerging from this research will reduce the vulnerabilities during and after an earthquake of essential facilities, such as hospitals, data centers, emergency response centers, power plants, transportation management centers, and telecommunication centers. The envisioned seismic protective options are flexible mechanisms tailored to control or avoid earthquake damage on a building's essential equipment and on its components, by reducing accelerations and by controlling deformations and displacements. The research will directly address critical needs of the earthquake engineering community by validating high-performance options to protect equipment and components of essential facilities. The resulting guidelines for analysis, design, and implementation will promote and facilitate the adoption of seismic protection for equipment and components to be used in essential facilities. The research has the potential to significantly advance current nonstructural qualification practices and fragility testing methodologies. The multi-faceted education program of this project aims to increase participation of underrepresented groups in STEM by bringing together students from Howard University to provide industrial exposure and interdisciplinary experiences for students, inspire K-12 students to pursue science and engineering careers by conducting outreach activities in the Washington, D.C. area, motivate undergraduate and graduate student interests in K-12 outreach, and integrate research and coursework.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview:

The major goal of this project was to evaluate and validate seismic protection options for sets and pieces of equipment and components in essential multistory facilities. The project involved theoretical analysis and real-environment full-scale laboratory tests of several passive systems.

Detailed analytical modeling was performed to evaluate the applicability and impact of various strategic settings in reducing the seismic vulnerability of vital equipment and components of essential facilities. Experimental studies to assess the seismic performance of different isolation/energy dissipation platforms for the protection of equipment under three-directional seismic floor accelerations was completed in 2014 at the Structural Engineering and Earthquake Simulation Laboratory (SEESL), at the State University of New York at Buffalo. This experimental testing program was possible via the shared-use of the George E. Brown, Jr. Network for Earthquake Engineering Simulation (NEES). The experimental studies included five different platforms based on (1) energy-absorbing wire ropes, (2) hinged-rubber bearings, (3) lead-rubber bearings, (4) negative stiffness vibration isolation platform, and a (5) pendulum-based columns platform. The platforms supported full-scale equipment and simulated equipment with different properties; including relatively heavy and rigid simulated equipment and relatively light-weight tall frames that held computer equipment. The different platforms supporting a piece of equipment were subjected to seismic shaking that intended to simulate a variety of floor accelerations of different multistory buildings under earthquake shaking of varying intensity. The project obtained industry support (materials and some technical support) for the experimental testing phase (Yahoo Inc. Seismic Foundation Control Inc. the VMC Group, Minus K Technology Inc., Roush Industries Inc.). Further, experimental studies were completed at the Applied Mechanics and Materials Research Laboratory at Howard University to explore different mechanisms to enhance the energy dissipation capacity of a type of steel isolators, and to investigate the mechanical properties of the wire rope isolators in different configurations.

Main findings:

Wire ropes can counteract seismic rocking by defining a wire rope configuration that eliminates/minimizes the distance between the center of mass and the center of stiffness of the platform. The wire ropes platform can control the deformation response of slender rigid-frames.

Platforms based on lead rubber bearings are able to control the horizontal accelerations and displacements on the equipment when subjected to ground and floor accelerations. Results from the lead rubber platform demonstrated the feasibility of achieving isolation of accelerations at roof levels.

The introduction of the hinge underneath the rubber bearing to conform the hinge-rubber platform increased the horizontal flexibility of the system. The hinge-rubber platform can control the horizontal accelerations at top of relatively heavy equipment.

The negative stiffness platform can control three directional acceleration and displacement responses for relatively light equipment under low intensity motions; however, due to the design mechanism, the platform is not suitable to achieve large displacement demands under earthquake shaking representative of high seismicity areas. Additional damping of the negative stiffness platform will enhance its seismic performance.

The displacement control thought damping is essential in all protective measures for the seismic protection of any piece of equipment located at different floors of buildings. The exploration of cost-effective damping measures to increase the dissipation capacity of the isolation/energy dissipation platforms to control displacement is a research need reinforced from the studies.

This project has contributed to the training of one postdoctoral associate, three Ph.D. students, three MS students, and 12 undergraduate students researchers. The major outreach activities of the project are concentrated on undergraduate research opportunities and in K12 outreach initiatives via the engineering ambassador program. This project supported the engineering ambassador program (EAP) engaging undergraduate engineering students in outreach to K-12 and the general public in the promotion of careers in engineering. The program allows hands-on experiences in the Washington DC area to educate children about tsunamis, earthquakes, coastal and earthquake-structural engineering. During the course of this project, EAP have successfully participated at the Discover Engineering Family Day that is held at the National Building Museum in Washington, DC. EAP coordinated and run different activities in the area including SHPE/USPTO Noche de Ciencias hosted by the United States Patent and Trademark Office, annual AAAs Family Science Day, Howard University Summer Transportation Institute, the National Center for Blind Youth in Science program-NFB STEM-X, and local K-12 schools and libraries.
